message.content:
You're right that it doesn't have to be completely either/or, but honestly, the middle-ground approaches you mentioned are exactly where I'm seeing some of the biggest challenges play out in practice.

We tried the local capacity building approach with a water project last year - training community members to maintain the systems, sourcing locally when possible. But what happened was that the local suppliers couldn't meet the quality standards consistently, the trained technicians left for better-paying jobs in the city, and when the system broke down six months later, the community was actually worse off than before because they'd become dependent on the improved infrastructure.

And when we ask communities what they want, of course they say they want the wells, the schools, the medical supplies - who wouldn't want immediate relief from suffering? But I'm not sure that's the same as asking whether they think it's the best long-term approach. It feels almost manipulative to ask people who are watching their children get sick from dirty water whether they'd prefer we focus on policy advocacy instead.

The thing that really gets to me is that I've started to see how our presence changes local dynamics in ways we never intended. Local governments sometimes reduce their own spending on infrastructure because they know NGOs will fill the gap. Small businesses can't compete with free distribution of goods. Traditional community leadership structures get bypassed when we work through our own local partners.

I'm starting to wonder if the real ethical question isn't just about aid effectiveness, but about power and agency. Are we inadvertently treating symptoms while reinforcing the very power imbalances that create the problems in the first place? And if so, what does that mean for someone like me who got into this work specifically to help people?
